name: SMIC
key_products: Contract wafer fabrication from 180nm to 14nm FinFET and 7nm-class (N+2) process nodes. Serves mobile, IoT, automotive, and HPC markets.
technology_node: 14nm FinFET (mass production), 7nm-class N+1/N+2 (limited production), 28nm and above (volume)
profile: Founded in 2000 by Richard Chang, SMIC is China's largest and most advanced contract chipmaker, ranking third globally behind TSMC and Samsung. The company is the linchpin of China's semiconductor self-sufficiency push, having achieved 7nm-class production despite US export controls blocking EUV lithography access. SMIC's 2024 revenue hit a record 57.8B CNY ($8B USD), though net profit declined 23% to 3.7B CNY due to heavy capex of $7.3B on new fabs. The company is aggressively expanding with four new 12-inch fabs planned across Shanghai, Beijing, Tianjin, and Shenzhen.
key_facts: 2024 revenue: 57.8B CNY ($8.03B USD), up 27.7% YoY — record high
Monthly capacity reached 948K 8-inch equivalent wafers by end of 2024
Capex of $7.33B in 2024, among the highest in China's semiconductor industry
Overtook GlobalFoundries and UMC in 2024 to become world's #3 foundry by revenue
Dual-listed on HKEX (0981.HK) and Shanghai STAR Market (688981.SS)

name: Hua Hong Semiconductor
key_products: Specialty process foundry services: embedded NVM, power discrete (IGBT, MOSFET, SJ-MOSFET), analog & power management ICs, MCUs. Focus on automotive, industrial, and IoT applications.
technology_node: 350nm to 55nm specialty processes. 90nm BCD on 12-inch. No advanced digital logic below 55nm.
profile: Founded in 1997 as a national project backed by Shanghai municipal government and NEC, Hua Hong is China's second-largest foundry specializing in mature-node specialty processes rather than advanced logic. The company operates 8-inch fabs in Shanghai and has built a major 12-inch fab complex in Wuxi, with Phase II entering pilot production in late 2024. Hua Hong runs at near-100% utilization thanks to strong demand for power semiconductors and automotive chips. The company is dual-listed on HKEX and Shanghai STAR Market.

Monthly capacity: 391K 8-inch equivalent wafers as of Q4 2024
Wuxi Phase II 12-inch fab (83K wafers/month) entered pilot production late 2024
Achieved mass production of 12-inch 90nm BCD process for automotive power management
Specialty in embedded flash, power discrete, and analog ICs — not competing on advanced nodes

name: Nexchip
key_products: 12-inch wafer foundry for display driver ICs (DDIC), CMOS image sensors (CIS), power management ICs, and MCUs. Process nodes from 150nm to 55nm.
profile: Nexchip was established in 2015 as a joint venture between Taiwanese foundry Powerchip and Hefei municipal government, inheriting Powerchip's mature process technology. The company rapidly became China's third-largest foundry by revenue, dominating the domestic display driver IC market. Nexchip IPO'd on the Shanghai STAR Market in May 2023 with a 1,160x oversubscribed offering raising 9.96B CNY. The company is building a second fab (N3) in Hefei targeting 100K wafers/month at 55nm and 40nm for automotive CIS applications.

name: YMTC
key_products: 3D NAND flash memory chips and SSDs. Proprietary Xtacking architecture. Products include X3-9070 (232-layer QLC), consumer SSDs, and enterprise storage solutions.
profile: YMTC was founded in 2016 as a national champion for NAND flash memory, backed by Tsinghua Unigroup and the National IC Industry Investment Fund. Its proprietary Xtacking architecture bonds CMOS logic to memory arrays, enabling industry-leading density. In August 2022, YMTC unveiled the X3-9070 232-layer 3D NAND, achieving a then-record 19.8 Gbit/mm2 density. The US placed YMTC on the Entity List in December 2022, restricting access to American equipment and technology, but the company has continued expanding using domestic and non-US suppliers.

name: CXMT
key_products: DRAM memory chips: DDR4, DDR5 (up to 8000 Mbps), LPDDR4X, LPDDR5, LPDDR5X (up to 10667 Mbps). Capacities up to 24Gb per die.
technology_node: 17nm DRAM (mass production), advanced sub-17nm nodes in development
profile: CXMT was founded in 2016 in Hefei, Anhui, with backing from the Hefei municipal government and Hefei Industry Investment Group. The company licensed Qimonda DRAM technology and has since developed indigenous process technology. In 2024, CXMT unveiled China's first domestically developed DDR5 chips at 8000 Mbps and LPDDR5X at 10667 Mbps, narrowing the gap with Samsung, SK Hynix, and Micron. CXMT holds approximately 4.9% of global DRAM market share and is planning a $4.2B IPO on the Shanghai STAR Market that could value the company near 300B CNY.

name: HiSilicon
key_products: Kirin mobile SoCs (smartphone/tablet), Ascend AI training/inference chips, Kunpeng Arm-based server CPUs, Balong 5G modem, IPC vision chips, HiSilicon connectivity chips.
technology_node: Designs at 7nm and 5nm-class nodes (manufactured by SMIC). Most advanced Kirin chips fabbed at 7nm N+2.
profile: HiSilicon is Huawei's wholly-owned semiconductor design subsidiary, tracing its origins to Huawei's ASIC design center established in 1991 and formally incorporated in 2004. Despite US sanctions cutting off access to TSMC in 2020, HiSilicon engineered a comeback by partnering with SMIC for 7nm-class chip production. In 2024, HiSilicon's revenue roughly doubled YoY, driven by strong Kirin 9000S/9010 sales in Huawei's Mate 60/70 and Pura 70 smartphones. HiSilicon ranked third globally in premium Android smartphone SoC revenue in 2024 with 12% market share, behind Qualcomm (59%) and Samsung (13%).

name: UNISOC
key_products: Mobile SoCs (T820, T770, T760 5G platforms), IoT chips, smart wearable platforms, baseband modems, satellite communication chips. Fourth-largest mobile SoC vendor globally.
technology_node: Designs at 6nm (T820 flagship). Fabbed by TSMC and SMIC at various nodes.
profile: UNISOC was formed in January 2018 through the merger of Spreadtrum Communications and RDA Microelectronics under Tsinghua Unigroup (now New Unigroup). The company is the world's fourth-largest mobile processor vendor with 13% global market share in 2024, behind MediaTek, Qualcomm, and Apple. UNISOC dominates the budget smartphone and IoT chip markets, shipping billions of chips to emerging markets. The company completed a $552M private equity round in June 2024 at a 66B CNY ($9.1B) valuation and is planning an IPO.

name: Cambricon
key_products: AI training and inference chips: Siyuan (MLU) series cloud AI processors (Siyuan 370/590), edge AI chips, IP licensing for neural network accelerators. Software platform: Cambricon Neuware.
profile: Cambricon was founded in 2016 by brothers Chen Tianshi and Chen Yunji, who spun out of the Institute of Computing Technology at the Chinese Academy of Sciences. The company pioneered commercial neural network processor IP, with its early designs integrated into Huawei's Kirin 970/980 NPUs before HiSilicon developed in-house AI cores. Cambricon IPO'd on the STAR Market in 2020 and has become a speculative darling, trading at extreme valuations despite modest revenue. Its Siyuan 590 cloud AI chip is positioned as a domestic alternative to NVIDIA A100/H100 for government and SOE buyers.

name: Hygon
key_products: x86-compatible server CPUs (Hygon C86 series, based on AMD Zen 1 microarchitecture), Deep Computing Unit (DCU) AI/HPC accelerators. Targets domestic data center and government markets.
profile: Hygon was founded in 2014 and obtained x86 CPU design capabilities through a 2016 joint venture with AMD, which licensed its Zen 1 microarchitecture. This makes Hygon one of only three companies globally with x86 server CPU designs (alongside Intel and AMD). The company IPO'd on the STAR Market in August 2022 and has since become one of China's most valuable semiconductor companies. Hygon's C86 processors are the preferred domestic alternative for Chinese government and enterprise data centers replacing Intel/AMD, driving 52% revenue growth in 2024 to 9.16B CNY.

name: Horizon Robotics
key_products: Automotive AI computing platforms: Journey 3 (J3), Journey 5 (J5), Journey 6 (J6) series for ADAS and autonomous driving. Software development platform SuperDrive.
technology_node: Designs at 16nm (J5) and 7nm (J6). Fabbed by TSMC.
profile: Horizon Robotics was founded in 2015 by Yu Kai, formerly head of Baidu's Institute of Deep Learning. The company has become China's leading automotive AI chip designer, with Journey series computing platforms adopted by 27 automakers across 290 vehicle models. Horizon completed Hong Kong's largest IPO of 2024, raising HK$5.4B ($696M) in October 2024. The company holds over 40% of China's intelligent driving solution market share, with cumulative chip shipments exceeding 10 million units by 2025. Major investors include Alibaba, Baidu, and Intel Capital.

name: Naura Technology
key_products: Semiconductor equipment: plasma etch systems, thin-film deposition (PVD/CVD/ALD), oxidation/diffusion furnaces, wet cleaning systems, annealing. Also electronic components and precision parts.
profile: Naura Technology was established in 2001 through the restructuring of the Beijing No. 7 Electronics Factory (est. 1965), inheriting decades of state-backed semiconductor equipment R&D. The company has risen to become the #6 semiconductor equipment manufacturer globally by revenue in 2024 and the only Chinese company in the global top 10, competing with Applied Materials, Lam Research, and Tokyo Electron. Naura's product portfolio covers the broadest range of semiconductor equipment among Chinese vendors, spanning etch, deposition, thermal processing, and cleaning — making it the cornerstone of China's equipment localization strategy.

name: AMEC
key_products: Plasma etch equipment (CCP and ICP): Primo series for dielectric, conductor, and TSV etch. MOCVD equipment: Prismo series for LED and compound semiconductor epitaxy. Competing with Lam Research and Tokyo Electron.
profile: AMEC was founded in 2004 by Gerald Yin, a former VP at Applied Materials, who returned to China to build a world-class etch equipment company. The company IPO'd on the STAR Market in 2019 and has since become China's second-largest semiconductor equipment vendor. AMEC's CCP etch tools are qualified at TSMC down to 5nm nodes, and its MOCVD systems hold significant global market share in LED manufacturing. In 2024, etch equipment revenue surged 54.7% to 7.28B CNY as Chinese fabs aggressively localized their equipment supply chains.

name: SMEE
key_products: DUV lithography systems: SSA600 series (90nm resolution), SSA800-10W immersion scanner (28nm-class). Advanced packaging lithography (37% global market share). LED lithography (55% global share).
profile: SMEE was founded in 2002 with a mandate to develop China's indigenous lithography capability — the most critical and restricted semiconductor equipment. The company's SSA600 series achieves 90nm resolution for mature-node production, while the SSA800-10W immersion scanner, completed in late 2023, targets 28nm-class patterning. SMEE dominates global advanced packaging lithography (37% share) and LED lithography (55% share). In 2025, SMEE restructured by spinning off its mature lithography business into AMIES while retaining next-generation R&D including EUV lithography development. An IPO was prepared but withdrawn in October 2024.

name: JCET
key_products: Advanced packaging (fan-out, 2.5D/3D, SiP, flip chip, bumping), wafer-level packaging, wire bonding, testing. Turnkey back-end semiconductor manufacturing. Acquired SanDisk Shanghai (80% stake) in 2024.
profile: JCET traces its origins to 1972 as a state-owned electronics factory in Jiangyin, Jiangsu province. Through organic growth and the transformative 2015 acquisition of Singapore's STATS ChipPAC for $1.8B, JCET became China's largest and the world's third-largest OSAT (outsourced semiconductor assembly and test) company. Advanced packaging accounts for over 72% of 2024 revenue, positioning JCET as a critical enabler for AI and HPC chips in China. The company acquired an 80% stake in SanDisk Shanghai in late 2024 to expand its memory packaging capabilities.

name: Tongfu Microelectronics
key_products: IC packaging and testing: advanced packaging (FC-BGA, FC-CSP, SiP, 2.5D), wafer bumping, system-level testing. Key AMD packaging partner for CPU and GPU products.
profile: Tongfu Microelectronics was founded in 1994 as Nantong Fujitsu Microelectronics (NFME), a joint venture with Fujitsu. The company renamed to Tongfu in 2016 and has become China's second-largest OSAT company. A pivotal partnership with AMD — stemming from AMD's 2016 divestiture of its Suzhou and Penang packaging operations into an 85/15 JV with Tongfu — gives the company deep expertise in advanced x86 CPU and GPU packaging. Tongfu is a key node in China's semiconductor supply chain, packaging AMD processors, Qualcomm chips, and domestic designs.

name: San'an Optoelectronics
key_products: LED epitaxial wafers and chips, SiC substrates and power devices, GaN RF and power devices, GaAs optoelectronic chips, InP photonic chips, sapphire substrates. STMicroelectronics SiC JV in Chongqing.
profile: San'an Optoelectronics was founded in 2000 in Xiamen, Fujian, and has grown into China's largest compound semiconductor IDM (integrated device manufacturer). The company dominates domestic LED chip production and has aggressively diversified into SiC and GaN power/RF devices for the EV and 5G markets. San'an's subsidiary Hunan Sanan Semiconductor opened China's first vertically integrated SiC production line in Changsha with a $2.5B investment. In 2023, San'an formed a $3.2B SiC device manufacturing JV with STMicroelectronics in Chongqing, signaling global validation of its compound semiconductor capabilities.

name: Silan Micro
key_products: Power semiconductors (IGBT, MOSFET, SiC, diodes), IPM/PIM power modules, AC-DC and DC-DC converters, LED drivers, MEMS sensors (accelerometers, gyroscopes), MCU ICs. Automotive and industrial focus.

profile: Silan Micro was founded in 1997 in Hangzhou and became the first IC design company to list on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in March 2003. The company has since evolved into China's largest IDM (integrated device manufacturer) for power semiconductors, operating three fabs (5/6/8-inch) and two packaging plants. Silan is a world top-2 player in the 6-inch and below power chip segment and is aggressively investing in 8-inch SiC power device manufacturing to serve the booming EV market. The company raised 6.5B CNY in 2022 via private placement to expand vehicle power semiconductor capacity.
